title: McKinnon quits, shock put down for Panthers
text:
ALEX McKinnon has announced he has stepped away from his role with Newcastle. 
Meanwhile, a Penrith great has his say on the Panthers’ 2017 chances. 
And how a gun Canberra player stays grounded. 
Catch the latest rugby league news in Media Watch! 
McKINNON STEPS AWAY FROM KNIGHTS ROLE 
Alex McKinnon has quit his role as Newcastle’s recruitment co-ordinator for the club’s elite pathways program. 
The former NRL forward confirmed via the club’s website that he would step away from the role, but remain involved as a scout for the Knights. NRL CEO Todd Greenberg and former rugby league player Alex McKinnon. Picture: Adam Taylor Source: News Corp Australia 
“It’s a sad day for myself, it’s hard telling people that have helped me so much over the last year and a half but I need to get out of my comfort zone, I can’t put all my eggs in one basket, I need to challenge myself and just go for it,” McKinnon said. 
The 25-year-old said he would like to become involved in public speaking. 
‘PANTHERS A YEAR AWAY’ 
Former Penrith star Ryan Girdler believes it’s too early to be labelling the Panthers as premiership favourites. 
The mountain men have one of the most exciting rosters in the competition and many experts are saying they can go all the way. 'Panthers a year away' 0:48 
“I think it’s a little bit unfair to have them going in as favourites,” Girdler told NRL Tonight . 
“They’re a young side with young players in key positions and I think that’s where they’ll struggle at the back end of the season. 
“They’ll be there when the whips are cracking, but if you put them against the Storm or Cowboys in a prelim final, I’m just not sure they’re there yet. 
“I think next year will be there year.” 
JOB GROUNDING RAIDERS GUN 
He’s one of the brightest young stars in the competition with his whole first grade career ahead of him, but Nick Cotric has revealed he still takes time out of his busy schedule to help out at his family restaurant. 
The 18-year-old, who will make his NRL debut on Saturday against North Queensland, has just finished his first full pre-season with the Raiders’ first grade squad. Nick Cotric at Raiders headquarters in Canberra. Picture: Kym Smith Source: News Corp Australia 
But despite all the hype surrounding him, he hasn’t forgotten where he’s come from. 
“I’d work there every day if I could, but now it’s pretty hard with training so I just go once or twice a week and just do what Dad says,” Cotric told The Canberra Times . 
“I just bake the pizzas, make pizzas and just serve customers sometimes or just clean up out the back.” 
Ben Ikin, Nathan Ryan and Ben Glover are joined by Raiders director of recruitment Peter Mulholland to discuss Canberra’s season-eve wheeling and dealing as well as all the big headlines from the off-season transfer bonanza.

‘IT’S A WORK IN PROGRESS’ 
South Sydney star Sam Burgess has been criticised at times for his fiery temper during games. 
Even Brisbane and England coach Wayne Bennett had a bit to say during the Four Nations tournament. 
The big bopper has hinted we may see a different side of him on the field this season. Burgess working on aggression 1:11 
“I get on really well with Wayne ... he’s got his reasons for saying that,” Burgess told NRL Tonight . 
“It’s been a work (in progress) my whole career — being on that line of aggression and going over it. 
“To play in the NRL, you need a certain level of that. It’s just whether you can use it in the right ways. 
“ ... I’ll take that on board and I’ve been working on it through the pre-season. People have been niggling me, but I’ve just been keeping calm. We’ll see how we go this year.” 
GIRDLER: POWER GAME THE KEY 
Former NRL star Ryan Girdler is looking forward to an evolving style of football this season. 
Girdler believes we’ll see more sides play a more entertaining brand. Girdler: Power game is key 0:59 
“At the back end of last year, I think there was a fundamental change in some of the styles with some of the teams who were successful,” Girdler told NRL Tonight. 
“I’m excited to see some of those sides go around this year. 
“Simple go-forward through the middle, simple dummy half play, some variations and then giving the players some football at a retreating defensive line. 
“Canberra and Penrith were doing it at the back end of last year and I think we’ll see some other teams follow suit.”
